Washington, DC; Dhaka, Bangladesh; Bonn, Germany: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI); Data Analysis and Technical Assistance (DATA); Center for Development Research (ZEF). http://dx.doi.org/10.7910/DVN/27704
latestVersion.disclaimer:
IFPRI adheres to the principle of unrestricted public access to its own final research outputs and will make such outputs freely available. The Institute encourages the use of the Bangladesh Climate Change Adaptation Survey (BCCAS), Round I dataset. For detailed information on its use, please refer to IFPRI's Intellectual Property Policy . The data files in this dataset are unit record or “raw” data file s. Information that would allow survey respondents to be identified has been deleted from the files, but all other information remains. IFPRI 's decision not to alter the contents of the data files means that the user of these files will need to take care in handling missing observations, outliers, and violations of logical consistency.

The data are provided “as is” and in no event shall IFPRI be liable for any damages resulting from use of the data. While great effort was taken to obtain high-quality data, the accuracy or reliability of the data is not guaranteed or warranted in any way.

fields.value: Bangladesh Climate Change Adaptation Survey (BCCAS),  Round I

dsDescriptionValue.value: The Bangladesh Climate Change Adaptation Survey (BCCAS), Round I contains data on 800 farming households. It provides information on demographic characteristics, social capital, land tenure, crop and livestock management, input use, extension, incidence of climatic shocks in the last five years and adaptation options. The survey was conducted from December 2010 to February 2011, covering data from the previous production year. It covers households in the 7 broad agroecological zones a s grouped by the Bangladesh Center for Advanced Studies.

publicationCitation.value: Thomas, Timothy; Mainuddin, Khandaker; Chiang Catherine; Rahman, Aminur; Haque, Anwarul; Islam, Nazria; Quasem, Saad; and Sun, Yan. 2013. Agriculture and Adaptation in Bangladesh: Current and Projected Impacts of Climate Change. IFPRI Discussion Paper 0128.  Washington, DC: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI)

Rakib, Muntaha; and Matz, Julia Anna. The impact of shocks on gender-differentiated asset dynamics in Bangladesh. Journal of Development Studies (2015). Article in Press. First published online on October 12, 2015.

Rakib, Muntaha and Matz, Julia Anna. 2014. The impact of shocks on gender-differentiated asset dynamics in Bangladesh. IFPRI Discussion Paper 1356. Washington, DC: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI).

Rakib, M. and J.A. Matz. Protecting Assets and Enhancing Welfare: The Gender-Differentiated Potential of Group-Based Approaches in Bangladesh. CAPRi Working Paper No. 119. Washington, DC: International Food Policy Research Institute.

Rakib, Muntaha. 2014. Strategies for coping with and adapting to climate change: Evidence from agricultural households in Bangladesh. In Enhancing women’s assets to manage risk under climate change: Potential for group-based approaches, ed. Claudia Ringler, Agnes R. Quisumbing, Elizabeth Bryan, and Ruth Suseela Meinzen-Dick. Pp. 50-53. Washington, DC: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI).

Rakib, Muntaha and Matz, Julia Anna. 2014. The impact of shocks on gender-differentiated asset dynamics: Evidence from Bangladesh. In Enhancing women’s assets to manage risk under climate change: Potential for group-based approaches, ed. Claudia Ringler, Agnes R. Quisumbing, Elizabeth Bryan, and Ruth Suseela Meinzen-Dick. Pp. 25-28. Washington, DC: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI).

Rakib, Muntaha and Matz, Julia Anna. 2014. Protecting assets and enhancing welfare: The potential of gender-differentiated group-based approaches. In Enhancing women’s assets to manage risk under climate change: Potential for group-based approaches, ed. Claudia Ringler, Agnes R. Quisumbing, Elizabeth Bryan, and Ruth Suseela Meinzen-Dick. Pp. 54-56. Washington, DC: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI).

value: Bangladesh Climate Change Adaptation Survey (BCCAS), Round II

fields.value: The sample unions were selected to represent the various agro-ecological zones of Bangladesh. More unions were selected for the larger AEZs. Twenty agricultural households were randomly selected for each sample union (one village each union), making 800 the total number of households interviewed. It should be noted that if a sampled union is actually adjacent to another union that is already in the sample and they belong in the same AEZ, it was discarded and was drawn again.

The sample was designed to be reasonably nationally representative, based on an agroecozone stratification.  One of the main issues about developing weights is the population census was quite old, and there was never a census that specifically looked at farm households. Therefore, it was difficult to come up with proper weights.
